definition:
An analytic function on an open set is called [*univalent*]{} if it is
one-to-one.

For example mappings of the unit disc to itself
$\phi_a : {\mathbb{D}} \rightarrow {\mathbb{D}}$, where
$\phi_a(z) = \frac{z-a}{1 - \bar{a}z}$, for any $a \in {\mathbb{D}}$ are
univalent. The following summarizes some basic of univalent functions.

Suppose that $G,\Omega \subset {\mathbb{C}}$ are regions and
$f \colon G \to \Omega$ is a univalent mapping such that $f(G) = \Omega$
(it is onto), then

-   $f^{-1} \colon \Omega \to G$ (where $f^{-1}(f(z)) = z$) is an
    analytic function and $(f^{-1})'(f(z)) = \frac{1}{f'(z)}$,

-   $f'(z) \not= 0$ for all $z \in G$

[9]{} John B. Conway. [**]{}. Springer-Verlag, New York, New York, 1978.
John B. Conway. [**]{}. Springer-Verlag, New York, New York, 1995.
